subsc: Agricultural extension and research,Central government administration

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated as
            satisfactory, and sustainability is rated as likely. Overall
            performances of both the World Bank and the Borrower is
            evaluated as satisfactory. Lessons learned are the
            following: 1) Sustainability of research projects with a
            heavy emphasis on institutional development will not come
            about simply by securing continuous donor funding.
            Sustainability can only be achieved by research
            organizations developing management skills and processes to
            allow work on priority research to continue even in the face
            of reduced budgets envelopes, through strict financial
            management and by ensuring appropriate staffing levels are
            maintained. 2) The effectiveness of technical assistance and
            training would be increased if programs are well coordinated
            and linked technically to ensure they complement each other,
            and implemented early in the project to allow benefits
            coming from these activities to be felt during
            implementation and to allow new processes to be
            institutionalized before the project ends. In some cases,
            this might mean outsourcing management of these programs. 3)
            Procurement management capacity must be assessed
            realistically at appraisal. 4) Project implementation units
            are neither necessary or desirable, as they tend to isolate
            project activities from the mainstream operations of
            implementing agencies, possibly depriving it of high-level
            support needed for effective implementation and longer term sustainability.
